div.ab: through his demonstration, with a sorrowful regret.
left-middleOn the Veil which I have discussed in the chapter on Drawing, on abundant and simple Histories.

39. In the composition one should not tangle
or allow [figures] to intertwine one with another,
arms and legs, seeming to fight/do battle,
but rather simply, evenly, straight
things should follow one another:
I have also heard much praise, as/when
The figures in a History mostly appear
completely uninterrupted and in their entirety.
left-middleOn not entangling too much in the History, so that one thing does not obscure another; and on seeking to make most of the figures as whole as possible.

40. To harmonize with the nature of Art,
making figures or faces, as is the case,
we should make is so that one is seen
behind the other, indeed, even if it is
not necessary for anything to be there;
for this will make (as in a dark stable)
the shadowed figure appear to recede,
and our foreground figure will seem to emerge.
left-middleAlso to display the figures behind the principal figures: how they stand or sit on the ground, and behind the foreground face make another one, which is darker, to bring it out.

41. And further, we especially ought to make sure
in the History, as we have revealed elsewhere,
that when bringing many shadows together in a heap,
not to let strong darks be placed too abruptly
and forcefully against bright lights,
but rather against half-tones; then in the center
we should build up an even, strong light,
which, along with darks, will dissolve into half-tones.
left-middleMake in the foreground or middle ground an even brightness/light, which at either side fades from half-tone to dark.

42. In former times there long reigned a confusion
among Painters, foolish-minded,
that their Histories at a distance
were thought to be marble, or chessboards,
applying black on white, as printers printed;
but then came from Italy Mezzotints
in beautiful half-colored tones,
which dissolve behind everything like a mist.
left-middleThings showing light strongly against dark, similar to a chessboard.

43. It surely behooves us not to overlook but
diligently “plumb the depths”
to depict fully the meaning of the History,
while nonetheless luxuriating in our freedom,
not like Andromeda chained to the rock:
for the Painters, according to the testimony of Horace,
in all they are or are known to be,
have similar power to Poets.
left-middleSimilarity between a painting and a flowery field, where the eyes are like bees, happy among a variety of different artful blossoms.

44. We see that our ancestors, when they (namely?)
wanted to execute a devout History,
skillfully placed the most important figures
prominently in the front (as is well fitting)
very striking, easy to distinguish,
left-middleIn a devout History, making figures prominent.
